summary_points: 1. On March 19, 2025, Vulcan Materials Company's Liberty Quarry in South Carolina received an imminent danger order from the Mine Safety and Health Administration (MSHA) for two employees working without fall protection; corrective action was taken.
2.  The 8-K filing, dated March 21, 2025, reports a safety violation at a subsidiary's quarry resulting in an MSHA order, but no injuries.
3. The MSHA citation carries the risk of future fines and potential operational disruptions at the Liberty Quarry if further violations occur.
1. On March 19, 2025, Principal Financial Group, Inc. exercised a put option, issuing $400,000,000 of 2028 Notes in exchange for Eligible Assets and subsequently dissolving the associated trust.
2. This transaction involved the complete exercise of a put option established in March 2018, resulting in the issuance of $400,000,000 in 2028 Notes.
3. The company waived its right to repurchase the 2028 Notes, and beneficial holders of the 2028 P-Caps received the 2028 Notes on March 20, 2025.
1. AutoZone's net income decreased by 5.3% year-over-year to $487.9 million in the quarter ending February 15, 2025, despite a 2.4% increase in net sales.
2.  AutoZone plans increased investment in growth initiatives (new stores and distribution centers) during fiscal year 2025.
3. AutoZone will adopt ASU 2023-07 in its fiscal 2025 annual filing (expected by March 2026), ASU 2023-09 in its fiscal 2026 filing, and ASU 2024-03 in its fiscal 2028 filing.
1. On March 17th, 2025, T-Mobile amended executive RSUs and PRSUs to ensure vesting upon termination without "cause" or for "good reason," subject to a general release.

2.  Michael J. Katz, President of Marketing, Strategy, and Products, received a compensation letter agreement on March 18th, 2025, guaranteeing a minimum annual base salary of $975,000 and a minimum Target LTI of $8,575,000.

3.  If Mr. Katz's employment is terminated without "cause" or for "good reason," he will receive a lump-sum payment equal to two times his base salary plus target STI award, plus pro-rata and prior year STI awards, and vested or pro-rata performance-based LTI awards, along with health benefits and mobile discounts for up to 18 months.

1. Diamondback Energy, Inc. entered into a Term Loan Credit Agreement on March 21, 2025, allowing its subsidiary to borrow up to $1.5 billion to partially fund an acquisition of Double Eagle IV Midco, LLC.

2.  The $1.5 billion term loan will mature two years after the closing date of the acquisition (or potentially later, depending on a margin election),  with interest at a fluctuating rate based on Diamondback's credit rating.
3.  The availability of the loans is contingent upon customary conditions precedent being met; failure to satisfy these conditions poses a risk to the timely completion of the acquisition.

1. On March 20, 2025, Genuine Parts Company amended its syndicated facility agreement, increasing its borrowing capacity from $1.5 billion to $2.0 billion and extending the maturity date to March 20, 2030.
2. This represents a 33.3% year-over-year increase in borrowing capacity.
3.  The amendment to the credit facility increases Genuine Parts Company's financial flexibility to support working capital, capital expenditures, acquisitions, and other general corporate purposes.
1. On March 19, 2025, Entergy Corporation's underwriters exercised an over-allotment option for an additional 2,227,538 shares of common stock, increasing the total offering size.
2.  The additional shares were sold at an initial forward sale price of $81.87175 per share, subject to daily adjustments based on a floating interest rate.

3.  Entergy has forward sale agreements with the underwriters that settle between now and September 30, 2026; physical settlement of these agreements will result in dilution to the company's earnings per share.
1. On March 21, 2025, Xcel Energy Inc. issued $1,100,000,000 in senior notes, comprised of $350,000,000 in 4.75% notes due March 21, 2028, and $750,000,000 in 5.60% notes due April 15, 2035.
2.  The issuance of the notes was governed by an existing Indenture dated December 1, 2000, supplemented by Supplemental Indenture No. 19, also dated March 21, 2025.

3. The 2028 notes are redeemable at the company's option before February 21, 2028, at a price based on the Treasury Rate plus 15 basis points, while the 2035 notes are redeemable before October 15, 2034, at a price based on the Treasury Rate plus 25 basis points.
1. Carnival Corporation & plc reported record-setting first-quarter 2025 operating results on March 21, 2025, exceeding December guidance and raising full-year 2025 guidance.
2. First-quarter 2025 revenues reached a record $5.8 billion, a year-over-year increase of over $400 million, while net yields (in constant currency) were 7.3% higher than 2024.

3.  The company expects adjusted net income for the full year 2025 to be up over 30 percent compared to 2024, exceeding December guidance by $185 million due to improved revenue and interest expense expectations.
1. Rollins, Inc. launched a commercial paper program on March 21, 2025, allowing it to issue up to $1,000,000,000 in short-term, unsecured notes.
2.  On March 21, 2025, Rollins, Inc. amended its credit agreement, releasing four subsidiaries as guarantors.
3.  Also on March 21, 2025, Rollins, Inc. released the same four subsidiaries as guarantors under its indenture, dated February 24, 2025, for its 5.250% Senior Notes due 2035.
1. Insulet Corp raised $444 million in net proceeds from a debt issuance on March 20, 2025, and extended its revolving credit facility to March 20, 2030.
2.  As of March 21, 2025, Insulet Corp repurchased $419 million of its 0.375% Convertible Senior Notes due 2026, leaving approximately $381 million outstanding.

3. Insulet Corp amended its credit agreement to allow lender participations without consent, subject to conditions, and terminated call option transactions resulting in undisclosed payments to the company.

1. Dollar General's operating profit significantly decreased by 29.9% year-over-year in 2024, reaching $1.71 billion, primarily due to increased markdowns and higher sales from lower-margin categories.
2.  As of January 31, 2025, Dollar General had $6,331,076,000 in scheduled debt maturities.

3.  Dollar General plans to open approximately 575 new stores and complete 4,885 real estate projects in 2025, while closing 141 stores (96 Dollar General and 45 pOpshelf stores) as part of a store portfolio optimization.
1. Micron's Q2 2025 net income increased 20% year-over-year to $1,583 million, despite an 8% revenue decrease from Q1 2025 due to lower DRAM and NAND sales.
2.  Micron's capital expenditures for 2025 are estimated at $14 billion (net of government incentives) to support projected memory demand.

3. As of March 21, 2025, Micron has recently restructured its debt, including issuing $1 billion in 2035 notes, securing a $1.68 billion term loan, and establishing a new $3.5 billion revolving credit facility.
1. As of March 20, 2025, News Corp had repurchased approximately US$651,088,268.92 worth of Class A and Class B shares under its US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2. On March 20, 2025, 21,297,356 Class A shares and 10,509,128 Class B shares were repurchased, costing US$431,959,499.09 and US$218,539,834.56 respectively.
3. News Corp's stock repurchase program, authorized to acquire up to $1 billion in outstanding shares, has a stated aim to enhance shareholder value.
1. Home Depot's $18 billion acquisition of SRS Distribution in June 2024 resulted in a significant increase in goodwill and intangible assets on their balance sheet as of February 2, 2025.
2.  Fiscal year 2024 saw a 12% decrease in diluted earnings per share, falling to $11.54, while comparable sales decreased by 1.8% (excluding the 53rd week) compared to fiscal 2023.
3.  Home Depot anticipates a low-single digit decrease in comparable sales for fiscal 2025,  despite projecting a 5% overall sales increase and $4 billion in capital expenditures.
1. On March 13, 2025, Kroger appointed Ronald Sargent as interim CEO and Chairman, with an annual base salary of $4,350,000 and a grant of 60,515 restricted stock shares vesting after one year.
2.  No other noteworthy numerical comparisons were present in the provided text.
3. The provided filing does not contain any specific future impacts or risks.
1. Kelly K. Blacker was appointed President - Global Geographies of Expeditors International of Washington, Inc., effective April 1, 2025.
2.  Ms. Blacker has been with Expeditors since 1994 and previously served as President, Global Products.
3. The filing states there are no special arrangements regarding Ms. Blacker's appointment and she has no material interests in any reportable transactions.
1. Diamondback Energy, Inc. completed a $1,200,000,000 public offering of 5.550% Senior Notes due 2035 on March 20, 2025.
2. The offering was registered under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, and the Notes are senior unsecured obligations.
3.  The Indenture contains customary terms and covenants, including limitations on the Company's ability to incur liens and limitations on mergers, sales, or leases of its assets.
1. On March 20, 2025, Hormel Foods Corporation appointed Jeffrey Ettinger to its Board of Directors, including the Governance Committee and ad hoc CEO Search Committee.
2. The Hormel Foundation, an unaffiliated non-profit and Hormel Foods' largest shareholder (approximately 46% of outstanding common stock), is represented on the board by Mr. Ettinger.
3.  Mr. Ettinger's compensation will be the same as other non-employee directors, as detailed in the company's December 18, 2024 proxy statement.
